questions.text: A lady on a drug treatment with migraine with h/0 CAD came with chest pain and heaviness. Which drug is responsible?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In migraine, there is cerebral vasodilatation, so we will give cerebral vasoconstrictors. Serotonin agonist – 5HT1B/D agonist – like Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan, Almotriptan, Frovatriptan Zolmitriptan . all these drugs are vasoconstrictors useful in acute migraine.In a patient with history CAD, if you use vasoconstrictor, they will aggravate chest pain and heaviness. Diltiazem and NO donor having vasodilatory property they don’t cause chest pain Serotonin antagonist causing vasodilation – Pizotifen, cyproheptadine, Methysergide- useful for prophylaxis of chronic migraine, they don’t cause chest pain.

choices.text: Prescribe as it adds effect due to same mechanism
Don’t prescribe as combination is irrational
Don’t prescribe due to more side effects
Prescribe as it can relive cough more efficiently

questions.text: New drug codeine plus dextromethorphan was launched. What will you do?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) CODEINE is an opioid used as a antitussive, dextromethorphan is also a opioid useful for suppression of cough, combination of these two drugs (from same group with same mechanism of action is irrational) The purpose of combination should be to have better efficacy ( for that add different group or with different mechanism of action), to minimize side effects, to broaden the spectrum of action. Here the answer is don’t prescribe due to irrational combination. Codeine has a side effect of dependence.

questions.text: Which drug will worsen myasthenia A. Lignocaine B. Meropenem C. Digene D. Phenytoin
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) (A, C, D) Myasthenia gravis has antibodies against Nm receptors. Lignocaine & Phenytoin are Na+ channels blocker & K+ channel opener [Class IB anti arrhythmia drugs], Digene is a rational combination of aluminum & Mg, interferes with the neurons. Meropenem is a carbapenem, doesn’t worsen MG. Drugs That May Exacerbate MG- Aminoglycosides: e.g., streptomycin, tobramycin, kanamycin Quinolones: e.g., ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, ofloxacin, gatifloxacin Macrolides: e.g., erythromycin, azithromycin Tetracycline- doxycycline Nondepolarizing muscle relaxants for surgery d-Tubocurarine (curare), pancuronium, vecuronium, atracurium Beta- blocking agents- Propranolol, atenolol, metoprolol Local anaesthetics and related agents- Procaine, Xylocaine in large amounts Procainamide (for arrhythmias) Botulinum toxin Botox exacerbates weakness Quinine derivatives Quinine, quinidine, chloroquine, mefloquine Magnesium Decreases acetylcholine release Penicillamine May cause MG CNS drugs- CPZ, CLOZAPINE, PHENYTOIN.

questions.text: What is the dilution of Adrenaline for IM injection in anaphylaxis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Adrenaline is the drug of choice for anaphylactic shock. It is given as 0.5 ml of 1:1000 solution (i.e. 0.5 mg) i.m./s.c. injection. Intramuscular route (on Lateral thigh) is preferred because of variability in absorption from s.c. sites. Intravenous route is avoided but can be used rarely in much lower concentration (1:10,000).

questions.text: Patient with glaucoma (increase IOP) with Acute uveitis (red eye, keratitis, aqueous flare). Which drug should not be given ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In glaucoma treatment : primary open angle glaucoma, 2 types of drugs: 1. Increase the outflow : A. Uveoscleral outflow : prostaglandin. Trabecular outflow : cholinergic [miotics] , Netarsudil [Rhokinase inhibitor] 2. Decrease the secretion : Alpha agonists [brimonidine, apraclonidine], Beta Blockers [timolol] Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (brinzolamide, dorzolamide) The above scenario is Of uveitis : prostaglandin should not be given in inflammatory conditions. Mannitol contraindicated of patient has pulmonary edema. Beta blocker is contraindicated if patient has bronchial asthma Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors contraindicated in sulfa allergy.

questions.text: An epilepsy patient is taking Retigabine thrice daily. Now phenytoin is added. What should be done next.

questions.text: Match the following drugs with their target
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A. 3, B. 1, C. 4, D. 2 Trastuzumab is a mono-clonal antibody against the HER-2/neu. It is indicated in the neo-adjuvant management of metastatic HER-2 positive breast cancer. - Imatinib is a first generation tyrosine kinase inhibitor. Imatinib attacks BCR-ABL translocation and is used in Chronic myelocytic leukemia . -Sirolimus acts by forming a complex with an immunophilin called FKBP-12 which inhibits rapamycin(mTOR) .mTOR is a protein kinase that blocks cell cycle progression at the G1 phase to S phase transition. It is used in prophylaxis of organ transplant rejection. -Infliximab binds with high affinity to TNF-alpha and prevents the cytosine from binding to its receptors. Infliximab is used for the treatment for Rheumatoid Arthritis. Also used in treatment of Crohn's disease .

questions.text: Therapeutic index is a measure of-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Therapeutic index is a marker of safety of a drug. It is calculated by TI = LD50/ED50 LD 50 is the lethal dose producing 50% of adverse effects ED 50 is the effective dose producing 50% of the response. Narrower the therapeutic index, unsafe the drug becomes.

questions.text: Treatment of scrub typhus and unstable respiratory problem
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Doxycycline is the first-line treatment for scrub typhus. It is effective against the Rickettsial pathogens causing scrub typhus. While doxycycline is typically sufficient on its own, in severe cases or if secondary bacterial infections are suspected, additional antibiotics might be considered, but ceftriaxone or azithromycin is not standard for treating scrub typhus. The addition of ceftriaxone or azithromycin is not a routine part of treatment for scrub typhus unless there's a need to cover other potential infections or specific clinical scenarios.

questions.text: A young patient on treatment with drugs for MDR tuberculosis presents with weight gain, cold intolerance and lethargy. On investigations, there was high levels of TSH and low levels of T3 and T4 in the blood. Which of the following is the likely drug responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ethionamide is a second-line antitubercular drug used in the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB). It is known to cause hypothyroidism, especially when used in combination with para-aminosalicylic acid (PAS). The clinical features described — weight gain, cold intolerance, and lethargy, along with laboratory findings of elevated TSH and decreased T3 and T4 — are classic signs of hypothyroidism. Ethionamide can impair thyroid hormone synthesis, leading to these symptoms. B. Cycloserine is primarily associated with neuropsychiatric side effects such as depression, anxiety, psychosis, and seizures. It does not commonly cause hypothyroidism. C. Pyrazinamide is more commonly associated with hepatotoxicity and hyperuricemia, leading to gout. It is not known to cause thyroid dysfunction. D. Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic associated with ototoxicity (hearing loss and balance problems) and nephrotoxicity, but not hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A patient was started on antitubercular therapy. After 10 days, investigations were done. AST and ALT levels were within normal limits but serum creatinine is 0.9 and serum uric acid was 10 had Joint pain. What should be done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pyrazinamide is known to increase uric acid levels and can lead to joint pain due to hyperuricemia. Given that the patient has elevated uric acid and joint pain, it is advisable to discontinue pyrazinamide while monitoring renal function tests (RFT) and liver function tests (LFT) to manage and assess any potential complications. Continuing the rest of the antitubercular therapy (ATT) drugs while closely monitoring the patient's condition is appropriate

questions.text: A Haemophilia patient took Anti-retroviral drug and developed side effects like altered mental status. Which drug is responsible
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Tipranavir, a protease inhibitor, has been associated with neuropsychiatric side effects, including altered mental status, especially in some patients. Ritonavir, Lopinavir, and Darunavir can have side effects, but Tipranavir is more frequently linked with such central nervous system effects.

questions.text: Used to prevent daunorubicin induced cardiotoxicity
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Dexrazoxane is the drug specifically used to prevent daunorubicin-induced cardiotoxicity. Dexrazoxane is a chelating agent that helps protect the heart by reducing the formation of free radicals and limiting the oxidative stress caused by anthracyclines. It works by binding to iron, which prevents it from catalyzing reactions that lead to cardiac cell damage. Here's why the other options are not suitable for this purpose: Aprepitant is an antiemetic used primarily to prevent nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy, not to protect against cardiotoxicity. Amifostine is a radioprotector used to protect normal tissues from the effects of radiation therapy and does not have a specific role in preventing cardiotoxicity from anthracyclines. Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used to manage inflammation and can help reduce side effects of chemotherapy, but it does not directly address cardiotoxicity caused by daunorubicin.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is used to prevent painful vaso-oclusive crisis & decrease long term complications in Sickle cell anaemia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hydroxyurea is a key medication in the management of sickle cell anemia. It works through several mechanisms: 1. Increasing Fetal Hemoglobin (HbF) Levels: Hydroxyurea promotes the production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF), which inhibits the sickling of red blood cells. Higher HbF levels help reduce the frequency and severity of vaso-occlusive crises, which are painful episodes caused by blocked blood flow due to sickled cells. 2. Reducing White Blood Cell Count: Hydroxyurea lowers the white blood cell count (WBC), which reduces the inflammatory response and the likelihood of vaso-occlusive events. 3. Reducing Oxidative Stress: The drug also has antioxidant properties that help reduce oxidative stress on red blood cells, further preventing their sickling and related complications. Other options listed: Methotrexate plus leucovorin is used primarily in the treatment of certain cancers and autoimmune diseases, not for sickle cell anemia. Methotrexate is a chemotherapy agent, and leucovorin is a folic acid derivative used to mitigate methotrexate toxicity, not for managing sickle cell anemia. Methionine is an amino acid and is not used in the treatment of sickle cell anemia. While it has various metabolic functions, it does not play a role in preventing vaso-occlusive crises in sickle cell anemia. Eltrombopag is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist used to increase platelet counts in conditions like chronic immune thrombocytopenia, not for sickle cell anemia

questions.text: Present with purpura n diagnosed as isolated thrombocytopenia. Tyrosine kinase inhibitor used in isolated thrombocytopenia is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Fostamatinib is an oral spleen tyrosine kinase (Syk) inhibitor that is used to treat chronic immune thrombocytopenia (ITP). Here's how it works and why it is relevant for this condition: 1. Mechanism of Action: Fostamatinib inhibits spleen tyrosine kinase (Syk), which is involved in the signaling pathways of immune cells. By inhibiting Syk, fostamatinib reduces the destruction of platelets by the spleen and other immune-mediated mechanisms, helping to increase platelet counts in patients with ITP. 2. Clinical Use: It is specifically approved for the treatment of chronic ITP in patients who have had insufficient response to previous treatments. Other options listed: Oprelvekin is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist used to increase platelet counts in patients with chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia, not specifically for isolated thrombocytopenia. Eltrombopag is also a thrombopoietin receptor agonist used to treat chronic ITP and other conditions associated with low platelet counts. While it is effective for increasing platelet counts, it is not a tyrosine kinase inhibitor. Bosutinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used primarily for the treatment of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and is not used for isolated thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: All of the following drugs are used in thyroid storm except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Aspirin generally not recommended in the management of thyroid storm. Aspirin can interfere with the binding of thyroid hormones to proteins, potentially increasing the free hormone levels in the blood, which could worsen the condition. Therefore, it is avoided in the treatment of thyroid storm. Propranolol - This is a non-selective beta-blocker that helps manage symptoms of thyroid storm such as tachycardia, tremors, and anxiety. It works by blocking the effects of thyroid hormones on the cardiovascular system. Lugol's iodine - This is an iodine solution that helps inhibit the release of thyroid hormones from the thyroid gland. It is used to rapidly decrease thyroid hormone levels in the body, thus aiding in the treatment of thyroid storm. Acetaminophen - This is used to reduce fever, which is a common symptom in thyroid storm. It helps to manage the elevated body temperature associated with this condition.

questions.text: Which anti diabetic drug is recently approved for treatment of heart failure with low ejection fraction along with low urine output?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Empagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor that has been shown to have benefits beyond glycemic control, particularly in patients with heart failure. 1. Mechanism of Action: Empagliflozin works by inhibiting the SGLT2 protein in the kidneys, which reduces glucose reabsorption and promotes glucose excretion in the urine. This also has secondary effects, including reducing blood pressure and providing diuretic-like benefits, which can help in managing heart failure. 2. Heart Failure Benefits: Empagliflozin has been shown to reduce hospitalizations for heart failure and improve cardiovascular outcomes in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). This benefit is observed even in patients with low urine output, which is a common concern in heart failure management. 3. Recent Approvals: The beneficial effects of empagliflozin in heart failure were highlighted in clinical trials such as the EMPEROR-Reduced trial, which demonstrated its efficacy in reducing heart failure-related events and improving overall cardiovascular outcomes in patients with HFrEF. Other options listed: Linagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor used to manage blood glucose levels in diabetes but does not have specific approval for heart failure management. Rosiglitazone is a thiazolidinedione (TZD) that was used for glucose control but has been associated with heart failure risk and is generally not preferred for patients with heart failure. Insulin degludec is a long-acting insulin used for blood glucose control in diabetes and does not have specific indications or benefits for heart failure management.

questions.text: A patient presents to emergency with giddiness. There was history of local doctor prescribing him some drug for RA few weeks and he suddenly stopped taking that. On investigations, there was Serum K level of 6.0mEq/L, Na 139 dehydration hypotension 90/40 and blood glucose level of 40mg/dL. Which of the following drugs should be used as Life saving treatment of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The appropriate life-saving treatment for an adrenal crisis is A. Hydrocortisone. This corticosteroid will help correct the adrenal insufficiency and address the hyperkalemia, hypotension, and hypoglycemia associated with adrenal crisis. The other options are not the primary treatments for adrenal insufficiency: Sodium bicarbonate and insulin are more relevant for managing severe hyperkalemia in other contexts but are not the primary treatment for adrenal crisis. Hypertonic saline is used in certain scenarios of severe hyponatremia or other specific conditions, not for adrenal crisis.

questions.text: A child with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with acidosis and blood sugar of 400mg/dl was started on intravenous fluids. What is the further management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) First one hour normal saline followed by infusion of insulin This is the safest and most effective initial management strategy for a child with Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) after they've been admitted and IV fluids started. The immediate priority in DKA, especially in children, is fluid resuscitation to correct severe dehydration and improve overall circulation. Giving a bolus of isotonic fluids like normal saline (0.9% NaCl) in the first hour helps restore blood volume, which is crucial for kidney function and for safely preparing the body for insulin. Starting insulin too early or too rapidly, especially with a bolus, can cause dangerous shifts in fluids and electrolytes, increasing the risk of cerebral edema (brain swelling), a severe complication of DKA in children. Once the initial fluid phase is complete (typically after the first hour or two, and once urine output is established), a continuous, low-dose intravenous insulin infusion is started. This gradual insulin delivery helps to slowly bring down blood glucose and, more importantly, stops ketone production and resolves the acidosis without causing drastic osmotic shifts. Incorrect Options: Option (A) Insulin intravenous infusion Explanation: While a continuous insulin infusion is definitely needed for DKA, starting it immediately at the same time as initial fluid resuscitation isn't the standard of care for children. The first hour (or more) is dedicated to aggressive fluid replacement to correct severe dehydration and stabilize the patient. Initiating insulin before adequate rehydration increases the risk of rapid electrolyte shifts and cerebral edema, which are major concerns in pediatric DKA. Option (B) Insulin stat dose followed by intravenous infusion Explanation: This option is highly dangerous and strongly discouraged in the management of pediatric DKA. An "insulin stat dose" (a bolus) causes a very rapid drop in blood glucose. This swift change in blood sugar levels and the body's osmolarity creates a significant risk for cerebral edema. Guidelines for DKA in children universally recommend against an initial insulin bolus; instead, they emphasize a continuous, low-dose insulin infusion after the initial fluid resuscitation phase is well underway. Option (D) Only IV fluids Explanation: IV fluids are absolutely critical for rehydration and are the first step in DKA management. However, they are insufficient on their own to resolve DKA. While fluids can help reduce blood sugar somewhat through dilution and improved renal excretion, they do not address the underlying problem of insulin deficiency or stop the body from producing ketones (which cause the acidosis). Insulin is essential to switch the body's metabolism from a ketogenic state to an anabolic state, thereby correcting the acidosis and bringing blood glucose to target levels.

questions.text: A patient with ulcerative colitis presents with three episodes of blood in stools per day. What is the most appropriate treatment in this case?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 5-Aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA) is often the first-line treatment. 5-ASA medications, such as mesalamine, help reduce inflammation and control bleeding. The other options are used in different contexts: 5-Fluorouracil is used in cancer treatment and not for ulcerative colitis. Budesonide is a corticosteroid used for more severe cases or those not responding to 5-ASA, particularly when localized therapy is needed. 6-Mercaptopurine is an immunosuppressive agent used in cases resistant to conventional therapies.

questions.text: Indication to start Desferrioxamine in a child is above what level of serum iron
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The indication to start desferrioxamine in a child is typically when the serum iron level is above D. 500 µg/dL. Desferrioxamine is a chelating agent used to treat iron overload conditions, such as in cases of chronic blood transfusions or hemochromatosis.

questions.text: All of the following drugs are used for treatment of heavy metal toxicity except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Oximes, such as pralidoxime (2-PAM), are primarily used to reactivate acetylcholinesterase in cases of organophosphate poisoning, not heavy metal toxicity. They work by removing the phosphate group bound to the enzyme, allowing normal nerve function to resume. Since oximes have no role in chelating or binding heavy metals, they are not used in the treatment of heavy metal poisoning. B. BAL (British Anti-Lewisite, Dimercaprol) – BAL is a well-known chelator used to treat poisoning from arsenic, lead, and mercury by forming stable, non-toxic complexes that can be excreted from the body. C. Penicillamine – This is an oral chelating agent used for copper poisoning (Wilson’s disease) and also for lead, mercury, and arsenic toxicity. D. EDTA (Ethylenediaminetetraacetic Acid) – A strong chelator for lead poisoning, EDTA binds lead and other metals like calcium, forming soluble complexes that are excreted via the kidneys.

questions.text: Drug inhibiting ATP binding cassette efflux
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Verapamil is known to inhibit P-glycoprotein (P-gp), which is an ABC transporter involved in drug efflux. By inhibiting P-gp, verapamil can affect the absorption and distribution of other drugs that are substrates for this transporter. This interaction can impact the pharmacokinetics of these drugs. Other options listed: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker and does not primarily affect ABC transporters. Tacrolimus is an immunosuppressant and while it interacts with P-glycoprotein, its primary role is not as an ABC transporter inhibitor but as an immunosuppressant. Diltiazem is also a calcium channel blocker and does not primarily act as an inhibitor of ABC transporters.

questions.text: A patient of mild to moderate dementia refused to take oral drugs. Which of the following drug can be prescribed to this patient that can be used by some other route?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Rivastigmine can be administered transdermally via a skin patch. This alternative route is useful for patients who have difficulty taking oral medications or who may have issues with medication adherence. The transdermal patch delivers the medication steadily over 24 hours, which helps in managing symptoms of dementia with a more consistent approach. Other options listed: Memantine is available only in oral forms (tablets and oral solution) and does not have an alternative non-oral route. Donepezil is also available only in oral forms (tablets and orally disintegrating tablets) and does not have a non-oral administration route. Galantamine is available only in oral forms (tablets, extended-release capsules) and also lacks a non-oral route.

questions.text: A patient presented with exert nocturnal dyspnoea and cardiomegaly. Pedal edema On ausculatation there were rales in both the lungs. Which of the following drugs can be used to prevent the progression of the disease?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Captopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor that plays a significant role in managing heart failure. Here’s why it is used to prevent the progression of heart failure: ACE Inhibition: Captopril helps to reduce the workload on the heart by inhibiting the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II, a potent vasoconstrictor. This leads to vasodilation, reduced blood pressure, and decreased afterload on the heart. Improvement in Symptoms: By reducing blood pressure and decreasing the strain on the heart, Captopril can help alleviate symptoms of heart failure and improve overall cardiac function. Prevention of Disease Progression: ACE inhibitors like Captopril are known to improve survival rates, reduce hospitalizations, and prevent the progression of heart failure by addressing the underlying pathophysiological mechanisms. Other options listed: Digoxin is used to improve symptoms and control heart rate in heart failure but does not prevent disease progression. It is more often used in cases with atrial fibrillation or to enhance cardiac contractility. Furosemide is a diuretic used to manage symptoms of fluid overload and reduce edema but does not prevent the progression of heart failure. It is useful for symptom control rather than long-term disease modification. Carvedilol is a beta-blocker that is also beneficial in heart failure by reducing heart rate and blood pressure, which can help in managing symptoms and improving long-term outcomes. While it is important for heart failure management, Captopril is more directly associated with preventing progression through its impact on the renin-angiotensin system.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient underwent surgery under general anesthesia. Rocuronium was used as a muscle relaxant during the procedure. After the surgery, the patient has not regained muscle function, indicating prolonged muscle paralysis. The medical team needs to reverse the effects of rocuronium quickly to ensure patient safety and recovery. Which of the following can result in the fastest reversal ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sugammadex is the correct answer. It is a novel and highly effective agent specifically designed to reverse the effects of steroidal non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers like rocuronium and vecuronium. Sugammadex works by encapsulating the rocuronium molecules, rendering them inactive and allowing for rapid restoration of muscle function. It provides the fastest and most complete reversal, even in cases of deep neuromuscular blockade, making it the ideal choice in this scenario where immediate reversal is needed post-surgery. Incorrect Options: A. Glycopyrrolate is an antimuscarinic agent that does not reverse neuromuscular blockade on its own. It is often used in combination with neostigmine to counteract the muscarinic side effects (such as bradycardia, salivation, etc.) caused by cholinesterase inhibitors, but it has no direct effect on rocuronium or neuromuscular blockade reversal. C. Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that increases the level of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby competing with rocuronium. However, it is slower acting and less effective in cases of profound blockade. It is suitable for partial reversal and typically used toward the end of surgery, but it does not work as rapidly or reliably as sugammadex in deep paralysis. D. Edrophonium, another cholinesterase inhibitor, has a faster onset than neostigmine but a shorter duration and is less potent. It is not commonly used for routine neuromuscular blockade reversal today and is also ineffective in reversing deep levels of blockade. Like neostigmine, it would also require co-administration with an antimuscarinic like atropine or glycopyrrolate.
